executive_summary: The Product Warranty Insurance industry underwrites factory warranties for manufacturers and extended warranties for retailers and consumers. Product warranties insure major electronics, household appliances and other products against defects or damage and cover repair and replacement costs. Product warranty insurance providers have benefited from a jump in electronics prices, which has led to greater prices of premiums to insure these goods. Also, strong economic growth at the outset of the current period and the federal response to COVID-19 have benefited the industry, resulting in greater disposable income and a expanding housing market. These developments have resulted in more product purchases, ultimately generating new demand for product warranty insurance. Over the past five years, revenue has grown at a CAGR of 3.4% to $1.9 billion, including an expected decline of 0.2% in 2023. Profit is expected to climb to 15.3% of revenue in 2023, up from 14.5% in 2018.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increased Premiums, Disposable Income and a Strong Housing Market Have Benefited Insurance Providers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry revenue increased as higher product component costs increased premiums for warranty insurance. In addition, disposable income increased, resulting in more product purchases and a stronger housing market. The federal government passed substantial legislation to support the economy in response to COVID-19. This provided direct stimulus payments and tax breaks, driving per capita disposable income and product purchases, increasing purchases of product warranty insurance.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THIRD-PARTY PROVIDERS ARE CONVENIENT FOR CONSUMERS AND HAVE INCREASED COMPETITION
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The emergence of third-party warranty providers has been a positive trend in recent years, as consumers have increasingly used these companies for their convenience and low-cost pricing models. SquareTrade Inc. (SquareTrade) is an internet-based product warranty company, offering consumers various protection plans primarily for consumer electronics, appliances and home entertainment equipment. SquareTrade has grown rapidly because of its business model, which enables consumers to access their policies and pricing information online while providing highly rated customer service and a rapid claims response system.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Positive Shifts in Demand Trends Will Benefit Insurance Providers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Insurance providers will benefit from dynamic shifts in product demand concerning household appliances over the next five years. In general, more new products will likely be on the market, like energy-efficient or technologically advanced products, benefitting insurance providers. Consumers will continue to push for increased connections across their mobile devices, vehicles and homes, creating a market for smart home devices and related services. The growing popularity of these products will boost revenue by increasing opportunities for product warranty underwriting activities.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Investment Income Will Climb, Boosting Revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry's investment income will improve as the economy grows steadily and interest rates slowly rise moving forward, boosting industry revenue. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note will inch upward in the future, leading bond yields to rise and helping insurance providers generate more investment income while limiting profit declines. Insurance providers will continue investing more heavily in corporate bonds, resulting in greater returns than government bonds.

Many warranty insurance providers will continue pursuing leaner operations to keep underwriting activities efficient and limit profit declines. The growing popularity of third-party insurance providers will limit labor growth within the industry. Third-party insurance providers enable consumers to easily access their policies and pricing information online while providing highly rated customer service and a rapid claims response system. New entrants will enter the industry through automated and web-based operations. Larger insurance providers seek to acquire smaller companies with high growth potential to better compete in the industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Insurance providers derive the most revenue from underwriting warranty programs run by retailers. Retailers primarily offer extended warranties at various levels of coverage, with higher prices covering a wider range of product damage.

Manufacturers are estimated to account for one-quarter of revenue in 2023. Manufacturer or factory warranties underwritten by insurance providers are typically limited to protection against factory defects and wear and tear within a specific period or number of years.

Distributor and wholesaler warranties are similar to retailer policies in that they are offered directly to consumers or businesses purchasing the product at the time of sale. Many kinds of heavy equipment or durable goods are sold at the distributor level to individuals or businesses.

The consumer market has grown over the past five years due largely to the spread of internet services. Rather than buying a warranty policy at the time of sale in a retail store, more consumers are shopping online to find an inexpensive third-party warranty that may offer wider protection.

products_and_services.product_description: Warranties for consumer electronics account for more than half of industry revenue. This service segment includes policies that cover accidental damage, liquid spills or submersion, loss or theft. Different carriers' policies cover some or all of these situations.
Warranties for home appliances, including ovens, stoves, dishwashers, washers and driers, comprise the third-largest market and account for almost one-quarter of revenue.
Other products under warranties underwritten by insurance providers include heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) systems, like window units, hot water heaters and other home systems.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Unlike other industries in the insurance sector, the Product Warranty Insurance industry does not explicitly follow hard and soft pricing cycles. Since industry revenue is generated based on the sales of underwritten products, the industry follows general economic trends.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Disposable Income and the Number of Wealthier Households
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Disposable income levels dictate consumers' ability to spend on nonessential items, like cell phones, computers, video game consoles and other home entertainment equipment or electronics. In addition, wealthier households are more likely to purchase more expensive goods that justify an extended warranty.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Consumer Spending and the Housing Market
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Home appliances, the other major product group underwritten by the industry, are sold directly to consumers and households as preinstalled features of newly built homes and apartments. Demand for appliance warranties depends on consumer spending abilities and the housing market's health.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The Product Warranty Insurance industry provides underwriting services for products sold in the United States, whether manufactured domestically or imported. The industry records no imports or exports and has no international trade.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region comprises the largest share of insurance providers, accounting for more than one-third of revenue. Florida has the largest concentration of insurance providers in the country. The Southeast is the single-most populous region in the United States.

The West region accounts for the second-largest concentration of insurance providers. California is the largest state in the region where insurance providers are concentrated. The West is the fourth-most populous region of the United States. Businesses congregate in major population centers such as Los Angeles, San Francisco and Seattle.

The Great Lakes region comprises the third-largest concentration of insurance providers. The Great Lakes region remains one of the United States' manufacturing hubs, despite widespread offshoring. This encourages companies offering product warranties to set up shops in the Great Lakes region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act is the primary federal law governing product warranties. The law requires manufacturers and retailers to disclose a product's full warranty and make it available to the buyer before the purchase, enabling individuals to compare the warranty policies of different products. This requirement encourages competition in the warranty marketplace. The law also requires that warranties be written in plain, easily understandable language.

To operate in the industry, a warranty underwriter must obtain a Certificate of Authority to supply insurance products for each state in which it wants to do business. Underwriters must also comply with minimum capital and solvency requirements. The industry's regulatory oversight level has remained stable in recent years.

The Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Consumer Protection offers public information to help consumers navigate the purchase of big-ticket items, which typically include at least basic factory warranties. The Bureau of Consumer Protection also enforces compliance with consumer protection laws, like the Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: MISCELLANEOUS COSTS HAVE DECLINED SLIGHTLY BECAUSE OF IMPROVED PRICING PRACTICES
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Miscellaneous costs are expected to account for 65.0% of revenue in 2023, down from 65.9% in 2018. Loss and loss adjustment expenses (LLAE) refer to an insurer's claim liabilities (i.e., costs associated with making benefit payments to policyholders). LLAE has fallen over the past five years. The steady decline in LLAE signifies more disciplined risk management, including improved pricing practices and diversification of exposures.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Product Warranty Insurance industry has a moderate level of capital intensity. In 2023, for every $1.00 spent on wages, the average operator will invest $0.13 in capital equipment, up from $0.12 in 2018. Typically, this industry is more labor-intensive, relying on the skills of underwriters and other insurance professionals to help sell, underwrite and process product warranty policies. However, most capital expenses have come in the form of technology upgrades, as capital is needed for information technology as systems are used to track policies, payments and claims. Systems are also used by actuaries to model insurance risk, ensuring insurance providers have proper reserves in case of a catastrophic event. Companies have continued to improve their technology to provide better customer service, like efficient customer responses and user-friendly websites.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE INDUSTRY HAS EXHIBITED A HIGH LEVEL OF REVENUE
volatility_points.volatility_description: Several trends have contributed to growth in warranty premiums in recent years, boosting underwriting revenue for insurance providers and increasing revenue volatility. Rising prices for electronics, the largest product group for which insurance providers underwrite warranties, have hiked the premiums needed to insure these goods. Electronics and appliances are increasingly produced and sold abroad. Many of the largest manufacturers, like Samsung and LG, are foreign-owned.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Increasing Disposable Income has Increased Demand for Products and Warranty Policies
volatility_points.volatility_description: Increased disposable income has helped slightly lower revenue volatility, as demand for consumer products increases when disposable income is high. Consumer income levels have risen for most of the current period and demand for products and their associated warranty policies has moved in lockstep. In addition, the tremendous fiscal stimulus to meet the economic challenges of the pandemic has contributed to growth in consumer income levels.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Insurance providers in the product warranty insurance industry have contended with some technological disruption in recent years. Software has recently been developed to automate a part of the claims process associated with warranties. This has provided some downstream consumers to provide their clients with warranties directly instead of through insurance providers. However, rectifying a claim still requires human input to identify specific issues associated with products. Despite the introduction of new technologies, users have still preferred to outsource the entire product warranty process to insurance providers, insulating it from experiencing disruptions in demand.

Technological change in the product warranty insurance industry has occurred moderately. Warranty underwriters rely on computer technology and storage to maintain customer records, process financial transactions and handle claims. Unlike other insurance industries, product warranty policies are comparatively straightforward, and consumers typically do not require the advice of an insurance professional to understand a policy. This characteristic is also the result of regulation that requires warranty language to be clear and easily understandable. With these conventions in place, the rising accessibility of internet-based services has led to substantial shifts in industry structure. Disruptive companies like SquareTrade Inc., which offers after-purchase warranties for electronics and appliances directly to consumers, are directing the industry away from retailers that traditionally handled most warranty transactions. This trend is expected to continue over the coming years as broadband internet access becomes faster, less expensive and more widely available.

FAQs.question: How do you emphasize the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: Product warranty insurance providers emphasize the value of their services by providing consumers with the most detailed and lengthy warranty for their product.

FAQs.question: What media channels are you using to attract consumers and investors, if any?
FAQs.answer: The best place for product warranty providers to market their services to consumers is in store or on sites where consumers buy specific products, as warranties are usually added on at the time of purchase.

FAQs.question: Does your company have exposure to fintech competitors? How is it effecting your strategy moving forward?
FAQs.answer: Product warranty insurance providers face little to no competition from fintech competitors.

FAQs.question: Are your operations spread across the country or are your establishments more concentrated in a certain geographic location?
FAQs.answer: Product warranty providers tend to have a wider reach than most other insurance providers, as defective products can be sent to them.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that you stay up to date with software and technology trends?
FAQs.answer: Since the process remains labor intensive, the rate of technological change for product warranty providers remains low.

FAQs.question: How have you taken advantage of rising internet and mobile-internet penetration into the financial services industry?
FAQs.answer: Products warranty insurance providers have taken advantage of increased internet penetration by marketing their services online when consumers are buying specific products.

FAQs.question: How do you expect the proposed changes to Dodd-Frank to effect your business?
FAQs.answer: The largest portion of Dodd-Frank that affects product warranty insurance providers is the formation of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

FAQs.question: How have the increased capital requirements under Basel III affected operations?
FAQs.answer: Product warranty providers are not affected by Basel III.

FAQs.question: To what extent are you affected by hard and soft pricing cycles?
FAQs.answer: Product warranty insurance providers are severely less affected by price hardening and softening cycles compared to other property and casualty insurers.

FAQs.question: How does your profit margin compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins for product warranty insurance providers vary predominantly based on the products they provide warranties for.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that your pricing policy is appropriate? How does your company anticipate fluctuations in costs?
FAQs.answer: Warranty providers must be able to price policies accurately based on the item or product.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a positive reputation? How can you improve your company to receive better word-of-mouth recommendations?
FAQs.answer: A reputation for positive customer service is essential to sell warranties directly to consumers and to attract retail and manufacturing clients.

FAQs.question: Do you offer a diverse range of services? Do you cater to any specific market with the services you offer?
FAQs.answer: Clients may require a range of services from warranty underwriters, including: Parts ordering and fulfillment, Customer service training for employees, and Marketing services.

FAQs.question: How can you take advantage of an expected increase in the price of semiconductor and electronic components? Do you track this price index?
FAQs.answer: A majority of products covered under product warranty insurance, including household electronics and appliances, incorporate semiconductor and other electronic components.

FAQs.question: How can you take advantage of an increase in per capita disposable income? Do you track disposable income?
FAQs.answer: The level of disposable income influences consumer demand for new products, including appliances and electronic devices.

FAQs.question: How can you accommodate increased demand from households in this income bracket? Do you track the number of households in this bracket?
FAQs.answer: Households earning more than $100,000 annually are typically better able to afford, and more likely to purchase, expensive consumer products with accompanying warranties.
